author: By Andrew Das
title: Elana Meyers Taylor, a Star U.S. Bobsledder, Tests Positive in Beijing
description: Meyers Taylor and her U.S. teammate Josh Williamson joined a growing list of Olympians with the coronavirus. The schedule may allow them enough time to recover and compete.
content: Elana Meyers Taylor, a three-time Olympic medalist and one of the most decorated American bobsledders in history, said Tuesday that she had tested positive for the coronavirus shortly after arriving in Beijing for the Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Conductor in Demand, and in Control
description: Mirga Gražinytė-Tyla is a leading contender for top posts at American orchestras. But that doesn’t mean she’s interested.
content: MUNICH — Let’s get this out of the way: Don’t expect Mirga Gražinytė-Tyla to be the music director of a major American orchestra any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: With Low-Tech, Trench Warfare, Ukraine’s Army Isn’t NATO Caliber
description: The United States and its allies have trained and helped equip the Ukrainian army. But it has little resemblance to the kind of sophisticated, contemporary military that distinguishes NATO members.
content: POPASNA, Ukraine — The soldiers live in dugout bunkers, and cook all their own meals. They dry their wet socks on clotheslines underground. Many of their weapons are remnants of the Soviet era, half a century old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Fatal Gang Fight Spurs Nationwide Lockdown of Federal Prison System
description: The Bureau of Prisons’ unusual step indicated that it was concerned that the violence could have a ripple effect on other facilities.
content: WASHINGTON — The federal prison system was placed on a nationwide lockdown on Monday after a gang fight at a high-security penitentiary in Beaumont, Texas, left two inmates dead, the Bureau of Prisons said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jayson Greene
title: A Celebration of Rap, and a Shrewd Study of Its Lyricism
description: “What’s Good,” by Daniel Levin Becker, is a wide-ranging examination of hip-hop and its language games.
content: WHAT’S GOODNotes on Rap and LanguageBy Daniel Levin Becker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: How Do You Celebrate Your Culture Through Food?
description: Food is an important part of Lunar New Year celebrations. Do you celebrate? If not, tell us about another holiday that is special to your family.
content: Feb. 1 marks one of the most important holidays in Vietnam, South Korea, China and other Asian countries: Lunar New Year. Do you celebrate this holiday? Are you looking forward to the Year of the Tiger?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean, Caleb Kabanda and Nanna Heitmann
title: In Congo, Floating Pastors Follow Mobile Flocks Along Busy River
description: To find the faithful, preachers in some areas of the Democratic Republic of Congo hold church where the crowds are, on boats traveling the country’s water highway.
content: MBANDAKA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The ebullient soukous music had been blasting from speakers since before dawn, but at 8 a.m., someone aboard the brightly painted boat docked along the Congo River pressed pause, and a pastor picked up a microphone and began preaching at a volume easily heard on shore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: On a Smaller Stage, Rick Pitino Is Still ‘Demanding’ and Winning
description: At Iona, Pitino doesn’t have the “bells and whistles” of Louisville, which he left amid scandal. But he has a team undefeated in conference play and looking to return to the N.C.A.A. tournament.
content: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — Sunday was not unfolding as planned for the Iona College men’s basketball team. Visiting St. Peter’s was playing rough-and-tumble ball, which had landed Iona in foul trouble and out of sorts. The frustration was evident when Nelly Junior Joseph, a sophomore center for Iona, tussled fiercely enough over a held ball with St. Peter’s Hassan Drame that both players drew technical fouls in an incident that nearly precipitated a brawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott
title: Sundance Wrap-Up: 6 Movies We Like and One We Disagree on
description: Even virtual, the festival gave our chief film critics a lot to talk about.
content: For the second year in a row, the Sundance Film Festival canceled its in-person plans and went virtual, wrapping up on Sunday evening. It was quite a feast, with more than 80 documentary and narrative features. Here are six our chief film critics especially liked, and one they disagree about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Entered 2022 With $122 Million in the Bank
description: The former president’s overall war chest was more than double the cash on hand of the Republican National Committee.
content: Donald J. Trump’s political operation raised more than $51 million in the second half of 2021 as the former president continued to dominate the Republican fund-raising landscape in his first year out of the White House, according to new federal filings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Shooting Outside Minnesota School Leaves One Student Dead and Another Injured
description: Two suspects were arrested hours after the shooting, outside the South Education Center in Richfield, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis, the police said.
content: A shooting outside a school in a Minneapolis suburb left one student dead and another in critical condition on Tuesday afternoon, according to the authorities, who said several hours later that two suspects had been arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tobias Grey
title: A Mother and Daughter Go Sightseeing. They See Each Other.
description: In Jessica Au’s prizewinning novel “Cold Enough for Snow,” two generations communicate with words and what’s left unsaid.
content: COLD ENOUGH FOR SNOWBy Jessica Au
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Giulia Heyward
title: Historically Black Colleges Disrupted by Bomb Threats
description: At least 17 historically Black colleges and universities said they received bomb threats in the past two days, though no explosives have been found.
content: A series of unconfirmed bomb threats disrupted life at more than a dozen college campuses this week, drawing the attention of the White House and the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: DeSantis and the Media: (Not) a Love Story
description: The Florida governor and the mainstream press have had a rocky relationship that he has often worked to his advantage.
content: If Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida somehow becomes the Republican Party’s presidential nominee in 2024, two factors will help explain why: his mastery of his party’s hostile relationship with the mainstream media, and his relentless courtship of Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Jesus Jiménez
title: Two Officers Killed at Bridgewater College in Virginia
description: A 27-year-old suspect was caught after a widespread search at the college, about 40 miles from Charlottesville, the authorities said.
content: A gunman fatally shot a police officer and a campus safety officer at Bridgewater College in Virginia on Tuesday afternoon after they responded to reports of a suspicious person near a campus building, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Alan A. Stone, 92, Dies; Challenged Psychiatry’s Use in Public Policy
description: An iconoclastic thinker, he greatly influenced the evolution of psychiatric ethics, and guided the decision to take homosexuality off the list of mental disorders.
content: Alan A. Stone, an iconoclastic scholar who used his dual tenured appointments at Harvard’s law and medical schools to exert a powerful influence on the evolution of psychiatric ethics over the last half-century, died on Jan. 23 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Recalls Cars With Full Self-Driving to Prevent Rolling Stops
description: Tesla told the federal regulator that rolling stops were allowed only at intersections when no cars, pedestrians or bicyclists were detected but agreed to disable the feature.
content: Tesla is recalling 54,000 cars equipped with its Full Self-Driving software to disable a feature that in certain conditions lets the vehicles roll slowly through intersections without stopping.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Cried Without Knowing Why’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “I love you, sweetheart. I’ll never forget you.” For years, I puzzled over my grandfather’s last words to my grandmother. He wasn’t a religious man, and it was he who was dying. Was he confused? Delirious? Eventually, I stopped wondering, stopped trying to apply logic. After all, contemplating the mystery and simplicity of his words has given me comfort ever since, as I’m sure it comforted my grandmother before she passed. Perhaps it was his way of saying that their love would endure, that their bond was so strong it didn’t matter who was leaving, who was staying. — Kathryn Silver-Hajo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Russia, Tom Brady, Milky Way: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes and Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. and Allies Close to Reviving Nuclear Deal With Iran, Officials Say
description: A return to a 2015 accord is on the table, but the next decisions are up to the new government in Tehran, the Biden administration says.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and its European allies appear on the cusp of restoring the deal that limited Iran’s nuclear program, Biden administration officials said on Monday, but cautioned that it is now up to the new government in Tehran to decide whether, after months of negotiations, it is willing to dismantle much of its nuclear production equipment in return for sanctions relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Questions Remain After Highway Crash Involving Monkeys
description: A Pennsylvania woman who had contact with them says she has signs of illness, but no one else has reported symptoms. And the airline that shipped them is getting out of the business.
content: In the 11 days since a truck hauling 100 monkeys from Mauritius crashed in Pennsylvania, one woman who got close to the scattered crates of monkeys on the highway has been treated for possible symptoms of illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Let’s Bring the Supreme Court Back Down to Earth
description: To the extent that Biden has been open about the politics and the optics of this nomination, I think he’s done a service for the public.
content: A new vacancy on the Supreme Court means a new round of political theater over the beliefs and qualifications of the president’s eventual nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: Brian Flores Sues N.F.L., Claiming Bias in Giants Coaching Search
description: The former head coach of the Miami Dolphins claimed in a class-action lawsuit filed Tuesday that the N.F.L. discriminated against him and other Black coaches in their hiring practices.
content: Brian Flores, who was fired as coach of the Miami Dolphins last month and was rejected for new jobs with other clubs, has sued the N.F.L. and its 32 teams alleging that they have discriminated against him and other Black coaches in their hiring practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.765 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: Anders Behring Breivik, Killer in 2011 Norway Massacre, Is Denied Parole
description: Mr. Breivik, who killed 77 people in two attacks, has served 10 years of a 21-year sentence.
content: Anders Behring Breivik, the Norwegian terrorist who killed 77 people in gun and bomb attacks in 2011, was denied parole on Tuesday by a Norwegian court that said he “appeared devoid of empathy and compassion for the victims of the terror.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Medical Care at Rikers Is Delayed for Thousands, Records Show
description: A court filing on Tuesday shed new light on the effect of the city jail system’s staffing crisis on health care, with missed appointments leading to severe health consequences.
content: It started with a toothache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone and Maria Varenikova
title: Angry U.S.-Russia Exchange at U.N. Punctuates Deepening Ukraine Rift
description: With vitriolic accusations that echoed the Cold War era, the United States and Russia sparred in a bitter debate over the Ukraine crisis in a Security Council meeting watched by the world on Monday.
content: The United States and Russia bitterly attacked each other over the Ukraine crisis in a diplomatic brawl Monday at the U.N. Security Council, in a session replete with acidic exchanges that could have been lifted from the Cold War era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Job openings remained elevated in December despite an Omicron surge.
description: Employers posted 10.9 million job openings in the last month of 2021, a rise from November but shy of the record set in July.
content: The Omicron variant of the coronavirus has disrupted business and kept millions of people home from work. But in December, at least, it did little to cool off the red-hot job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How to Wake Up Your Staircase
description: You may not spend a lot of time there, but if you’ve got a staircase, it shouldn’t be ‘tired and dull.’ Here’s how to give it some personality.
content: Your staircase may not get as much attention as other spaces in your home, like your kitchen and living room, but it should. A beautiful stairwell can tie your home together and make moving from one level to another a pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Morning at Night: A New York Times Event
description: On March 9, join David Leonhardt for a live-streamed edition of the newsletter as we explore what Omicron signals about the state of the pandemic, and watch Modern Love editors share their favorite reader-submitted Tiny Love Stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Martin McDonagh’s ‘Hangmen’ Will Open on Broadway This Spring
description: The production, which was canceled at the start of the pandemic, will try again, this time starring Alfie Allen of “Game of Thrones” fame.
content: “Hangmen” has been saved from the executioner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Blames the U.S.
description: The Russian president accused the U.S. of inciting war in Ukraine.
content: Addressing the Ukraine crisis for the first time since December, President Vladimir Putin of Russia said that the U.S. was trying to pull Russia into an armed conflict over Ukraine that Russia did not want.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in February
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of February’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil reports a $8.9 billion fourth-quarter profit as oil prices soar.
description: The oil and gas giant said it would resume its stock buyback program by repurchasing $10 billion in shares over the next two years.
content: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil, the largest American oil company, reported its most robust earnings in seven years on Tuesday as it rode a wave of climbing oil and natural gas prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodman
title: A Town That Saved a Mountain, and a Mountain That Saved a Town
description: After the Ascutney ski resort in Vermont closed because of erratic snowfall and mismanagement, it threatened to take with it the nearby town of West Windsor. The community took the situation into its own hands.
content: Jim Lyall briskly skied up Mount Ascutney, eagerly pointing out the view. We were skinning up a ski area in southern Vermont, but the chairlifts are long gone. At the top of the mountain we arrived at an abandoned ski patrol cabin and lift station. A cold breeze whipped through the deserted structures. It had a ghostly, post-apocalyptic feel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Can Jennifer Lopez Save the Rom-Com?
description: After navigating the treacherous waters of celebrity, the superstar is betting on “Marry Me,” a movie that sounds a lot like her personal life.
content: LOS ANGELES — Of course the fireplace is lit at Jennifer Lopez’s house. It’s a rainy day just a week before Christmas, and her Spanish-style Bel-Air estate is decorated as you would expect: pine garland strewn around the mantle, orange roses on the coffee table, a professionally trimmed Christmas tree in the living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An ‘Eerily Similar’ Murder-for-Hire
description: New revelations about a killing in 2014 have prompted questions from the son of a New Jersey couple found dead in their home that year.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at two cases in New Jersey — one a murder-for-hire case apparently orchestrated by a political consultant, the other unsolved. A son of the couple in the second case sees a possible connection to the first. We’ll also tour a new terminal at La Guardia, the airport New Yorkers love to hate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: What an All-Women News Network in India Shows Us About Democracy
description: As Dalit women, they are  deeply familiar with living under threat.
content: It started out as a literacy project. Dalit women, formerly known as untouchables, hand-wrote a newsletter about issues that mattered to them: Broken water pumps. Unpaved roads. Known rapists walking free. In 2002 they started a newspaper that covered everything from illegal mining to murders. Perhaps because Dalits make up about 20 percent of the population of the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, some government officials started paying attention. Roads got paved. Toilets got built. Hospitals got stocked with medicines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Israeli Commanders Disciplined in Death of Palestinian-American Man
description: Three Israeli military commanders have been reprimanded and reassigned after an investigation into the death of a 78-year-old man after he was detained.
content: JERUSALEM — Three Israeli military commanders have been disciplined after an investigation into the death of a 78-year-old Palestinian-American man who was detained, gagged and handcuffed by Israeli soldiers in a night raid on his village last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Little of the Paycheck Protection Program’s $800 Billion Protected Paychecks
description: Only about a quarter of the funding went to jobs that would have been lost, new research found. A big chunk lined bosses’ pockets.
content: Hanging over the $800 billion Paycheck Protection Program, one of the government’s most expensive pandemic relief efforts, is a simple question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qian Julie Wang
title: For This Mountaineer, Everest Was a Challenge and a Path to Peace
description: In her memoir, “In the Shadow of the Mountain,” Silvia Vasquez-Lavado recounts how she climbed Mount Everest and how she transcended a past of abuse and alcoholism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: The Rampaging Pigs of the San Francisco Bay Area
description: A proposed California law would make it easier to hunt feral swine, the voracious ‘super invaders’ that are the bane of some East Bay suburbs.
content: MORAGA, Calif. — The residents of the San Francisco Bay Area go to great lengths to accommodate the wealth of wildlife around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The defense secretary tells Republican governors: National Guard troops must be vaccinated.
description: Lloyd J. Austin’s rejection of the governors’ request to exempt their states’ troops from the national military coronavirus vaccine mandate sets the stage for a possible court fight.
content: Lloyd J. Austin III, the defense secretary, has written a letter to seven Republican governors, rejecting their requests for exemptions from coronavirus vaccination mandates for their states’ National Guard troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Starbucks will raise prices again, citing higher costs for supplies and workers.
description: The company’s profit soared 31 percent, to $816 million, in the last three months of 2021.
content: Starbucks will increase prices this year, the coffee giant said on Tuesday, blaming supply chain disruptions and a sharp rise in labor costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: An 8-Year-Old Wrote a Book and Hid It on a Library Shelf. It’s a Hit.
description: Dillon Helbig, a second-grader from Idaho, wrote an 81-page book about his “Crismis” adventures. Now other children want to write stories.
content: During his Christmas break, Dillon Helbig, an 8-year-old boy from Boise, Idaho, wrote a book that he wanted everyone to read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Ski Blind
description: Only use guides who lead rather than follow you. At the top of the run, ask them for a play-by-play so you know what’s coming.
content: “You need a guide,” says Mike May, 68, who was blinded at age 3 in a calcium-carbide chemical explosion. May started skiing at 27, on a bunny slope, holding onto a guide’s poles — in what he calls “horse and buggy style.” Within days, he was unattached and following his guide’s voice down the hill. “It was extremely liberating,” says May, who went on to win multiple medals in the world competitions now known as the Paralympics, and hit 65 miles per hour to set the world record for speed skiing by a completely blind skier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Dutch Publisher Apologizes Over Disputed Anne Frank Book
description: Ambo Anthos Publishers said it would delay printing more copies. HarperCollins, the book’s publisher in the United States, declined to comment.
content: AMSTERDAM — The Dutch publisher of “The Betrayal of Anne Frank,” a new book scholars have criticized for putting forward inconclusive findings, apologized for “offending anyone” in an email sent to its authors, and said it would delay printing more copies of the book until further notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: The U.S. orders families of its embassy staff in Belarus to leave the country.
description: Washington cited “an increase in unusual and concerning Russian military activity near the border with Ukraine.”
content: With large-scale Russian military exercises set to begin in Belarus, the United States has ordered the departure of family members of U.S. government employees, citing “an increase in unusual and concerning Russian military activity near the border with Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Tom Brady Says He Hasn’t Reached Retirement Decision
description: In Brady’s first public comments since reports that he’d end his 22-season career, the only timeline he gave for making a decision was “when the time’s right.”
content: [Follow our live updates on Tom Brady’s retirement.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Luke Vander Ploeg, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum and Dan Powell
title: Did Democrats Make Inflation Worse?
description: Higher prices are imperiling the party’s chances of holding on to power in Washington. How much have Democrats’ own policies contributed to the problem?
content: Inflation in the United States has been getting worse. In December, prices were up 7 percent from the previous year — the fastest rise in 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: These Talkies Star Complicated Women You Might Well Recognize
description: A MoMA series puts the spotlight on a Hollywood era when actresses broke free of stereotypes that would later dominate movies for decades.
content: In that all-too-brief period in Hollywood between the silent era and the summer of 1934, when the puritanical Production Code Administration began to put a stranglehold on the industry, the women of the silver screen came into their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Russo
title: A Novel About Abortion, Told From Inside and Outside a Clinic
description: In “Mercy Street,” Jennifer Haigh examines a controversial issue from multiple perspectives.
content: MERCY STREETBy Jennifer Haigh
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: luminous
description: This word has appeared in 133 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word luminous has appeared in 133 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 11 in “‘Belfast’ Review: A Boy’s Life” by Jeannette Catsoulis:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Prices and Ire, Rising
description: Inflation is up, and Americans are mad. But it’s not a simple story.
content: Paul Krugman, the economist and Times Opinion columnist, asked an intriguing question last week: Why are Americans so upset about inflation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Intimate Apparel,’ Letting the Seamstress Sing
description: Lynn Nottage’s play about a Black woman in 1905 becomes an opera, with music by Ricky Ian Gordon, that forefronts voices ignored by history.
content: We begin with joyful ragtime, that musical theater fallback for telling Black stories of the early 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: White House Chooses Doug Jones to Guide Supreme Court Nominee
description: Once President Biden picks a nominee, Mr. Jones will introduce her to senators and prepare her for hearings.
content: WASHINGTON — Doug Jones, a former Democratic senator from Alabama, will serve as a guide for President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee during the Senate confirmation process, two senior administration officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Phillips-Fein
title: I Wouldn’t Bet on the Kind of Democracy Big Business Is Selling Us
description: “Stakeholder capitalism” does not offer a real alternative to broad political mobilizations that would benefit most Americans.
content: When Larry Fink, the chief executive of the asset management company BlackRock, wrote in his 2022 annual letter to corporate America that prioritizing environmental sustainability, racial justice and other social goals is not “woke” and “not about politics,” he articulated anew a longstanding hope that business can be a driver for social change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Chuck Klosterman Rewinds to ‘The Nineties’
description: The prolific cultural obsessive turns his attention to the twilight of a millennium, when Generation X reluctantly took center stage.
content: They’re baaack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India’s budget focuses on roads, but critics see need for more jobs.
description: Narendra Modi’s plan calls for a big increase in infrastructure spending. Some say more must be done to create jobs for the country’s young work force.
content: NEW DELHI — India’s government on Tuesday unveiled its annual budget, which proposed a significant spending increase for highways, road and airports, but a smaller increase for rural development and employment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Pochoda
title: These Characters Study Abroad in Berlin. It Doesn’t Go Well.
description: In Calla Henkel’s debut novel, “Other People’s Clothes,” two American art students take a new city by storm, with seismic consequences.
content: OTHER PEOPLE’S CLOTHESBy Calla Henkel
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Taking On Everest at Its Very Coldest and at Its Toughest
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 1, 2022.
content: “You have to be able to suffer. It’s the art of suffering.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Ducker
title: J Dilla Was a Revered Rap Producer. A New Book Deepens His Legacy.
description: The Detroit musician wasn’t known to give many interviews, and his influence has grown exponentially since his 2006 death. “Dilla Time” by Dan Charnas explores what drove him.
content: Even during his lifetime, there was something unexplainable about J Dilla, the Detroit-born hip-hop producer and M.C. He was an open secret, an under-acknowledged force shifting and shaping modern music. Followers spoke of him reverentially and with enough hyperbole that he could feel inaccessible to listeners who didn’t quite get it. In the 16 years since his death, the aura around him has only grown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: On the Cajun Coast, a Chef Grapples With Threats to a Seafood Tradition
description: From her New Orleans restaurant, Melissa Martin sees the environmental damage that could end the region’s rich culture of food and fishing.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Days before Hurricane Ida hit last August, Maxine and Lanny Martin bought 150 pounds of shrimp in Chauvin, the coastal Louisiana town where they live. The shrimp came from fishers along Bayou Petit Caillou, which runs a few blocks from the house where the Martins raised six children, including Melissa Martin, a chef and cookbook author in New Orleans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Billionaires and Big Checks Shape Battle for Congress
description: The party committees for Democrats and Republicans each raised about $400 million in 2021, with control of the House and Senate up for grabs in 2022.
content: Billionaires cut giant checks to super PACs. Small donors gave online in mass quantities. Multimillionaires poured money into their own campaigns. And both political parties announced record-setting hauls in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: To Skate for the Dutch, You First Must Beat the Matrix
description: The Netherlands will almost certainly leave the Beijing Olympics with the most speedskating medals. But just being fast doesn’t guarantee a place on its team.
content: When the speedskater Dai Dai N’tab finished second in the 500-meter men’s race during the Netherlands’ Olympic qualifying event in December, he thought he had secured one of the three Olympic entries at that distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Despite Labor Shortages, Workers See Few Gains in Economic Security
description: The pandemic has supposedly given service workers leverage. But many still have unstable hours and incomes because employers like the flexibility.
content: Over the past two months, Brenda Garcia, who works at a Chipotle in Queens, has struggled to land more than 20 hours per week, making it difficult to keep up with her expenses. When she confronts her manager, he vows to try to find her more work, but the problem invariably persists. In one recent week, the store scheduled her for a single 6.25-hour shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Thousands Told to Evacuate as North Carolina Fertilizer Plant Burns
description: The fire broke out at the plant in Winston-Salem, where more than 6,000 people within a mile of the plant were told to leave over worries of a possible explosion.
content: Thousands of people were ordered to evacuate from a neighborhood in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Tuesday as the authorities warned of a possible explosion from a fire burning for a second day at a nearby fertilizer plant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Greg Tate, Critic and Catalyst
description: Conversations with two of his contemporaries about the fertile scenes he covered, and the indelible impression he left.
content: Greg Tate, the pioneering critic, died last December at 64. His 1992 anthology “Flyboy in the Buttermilk: Essays on Contemporary America” is a startling document of the innovations taking place in the Black music, film and art of the time, and also a guidebook for a sui generis style of writing that was deeply lyrical on its own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Hanff Korelitz
title: Sex, Lies and Infidelity on a Small College Campus
description: Julia May Jonas’s debut novel, “Vladimir,” taps into a timeless story with several timely twists.
content: VLADIMIRBy Julia May Jonas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Neil Vigdor
title: ABC Suspends Whoopi Goldberg Over Holocaust Comments
description: Ms. Goldberg’s comments, on Monday’s episode of “The View,” came amid growing ignorance about the Holocaust and rising antisemitism. She has apologized.
content: Whoopi Goldberg, the comedian and actress who is also a co-host of the ABC talk show “The View,” will be suspended for two weeks, the network announced Tuesday night, after she said repeatedly during an episode of the show that aired on Monday that the Holocaust was not about race, comments that come at a time of rising antisemitism globally. She later apologized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ready, Set, Gerrymander!
description: A new interactive tool developed by The New York Times’s Graphics desk lets readers put their congressional-district-drawing skills to the test.
content: On Thanksgiving, three journalists on The New York Times’s Graphics team headed into their family dinners with an unusual mission: They wanted to talk politics with their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Tribes Reach $590 Million Opioid Settlement With J. & J. and Distributors
description: Money from the tentative deal would go toward addiction and treatment and would be overseen by Native American tribal leaders.
content: Hundreds of Native American tribes that have suffered disproportionately high addiction and death rates during the opioid epidemic agreed on Tuesday to a tentative settlement of $590 million with Johnson & Johnson and the country’s three largest drug distributors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Georgetown Suspends Lecturer Who Criticized Vow to Put Black Woman on Court
description: Ilya Shapiro has apologized after tweeting that President Biden was poised to nominate not “the objectively best pick,” but a “lesser” Black woman to the Supreme Court.
content: Georgetown University’s law school placed a newly hired administrator on leave on Monday after he said on Twitter that President Biden would nominate not “the objectively best pick” but a “lesser” Black woman to be the next Supreme Court justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Collateral Damage of Facebook’s Flops
description: Experimentation is great, yada yada. But it costs us when influential companies change their mind.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Parker
title: Hollywood Came to China; It Was Epic.
description: Erich Schwartzel’s “Red Carpet” explores how Hollywood wooed the Chinese market — and became the villain of the piece.
content: RED CARPETHollywood, China, and the Global Battle for Cultural SupremacyBy Erich Schwartzel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Keim and Greta Rybus
title: Groundhogs Emerge From the Scientific Shadows
description: New research aims to shed light on the social habits of the popular, but often misunderstood, animal.
content: FALMOUTH, Maine — Groundhog Day may be a tongue-in-cheek holiday, but it remains the one day earmarked in the United States for an animal: Marmota monax, the largest and most widely distributed of the marmot genus, found munching on flowering plants — or, at this time of year, snuggling underground — from Alabama to Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Amanda Litman
description: A conversation with the co-founder of Run for Something
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Amanda Litman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Calling All Tap Dance Kids (It’s Not the Acting Kid or the Singing Kid)
description: The challenge of casting the Encores! revival of “The Tap Dance Kid” exposes some of the complications of tap, show business and Black history.
content: If you’re going to stage a revival of the seldom performed but dearly remembered 1983 Broadway musical “The Tap Dance Kid” — as Encores! at New York City Center is doing, Wednesday through Sunday — one of the main challenges is to find someone to play the title role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Becker
title: I’m Thankful Every Day for the Decision I Made After My Prenatal Tests
description: These tests can offer information about the chromosomal makeup of fetuses but cannot prepare parents for the wonder within every human life.
content: Our 16-year-old daughter, Penny, wakes up to the beeping of her alarm. On her way downstairs, she picks up her iPhone to check her texts. She eats breakfast, gathers her sneakers and pompoms for cheerleading and heads to school. When Penny was diagnosed with Down syndrome a few hours after she was born, I didn’t expect our mornings to feel so ordinary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Nathan
title: Unhappy Families Abound in These New Books About Fathers and Sons
description: Three new books (by Adrian Nathan West, Daniel Black and Obed Silva) explore difficult family dynamics, each challenging in its own way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kisselgoff
title: Donald Mahler, Prolific Ballet Choreographer, Dies at 88
description: After dancing with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet and other companies, he became its director. He was also well known for his staging of works by Antony Tudor.
content: Donald Mahler, a ballet dancer and prolific choreographer for the Metropolitan Opera who was the director of the company’s own dance troupe, and who was also known internationally for his stagings of ballets by Antony Tudor, died on Jan. 25 in Roslyn Heights, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: President of Guinea-Bissau Reasserts Control After Fears of Another Coup in Africa
description: Military leaders have taken power in five African countries in the last 18 months, but Guinea-Bissau — a small coastal nation no stranger to coups — appears to have just staved one off.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunfire erupted near the presidential palace. Military trucks raced through the streets as civilians fled. The country’s president vanished from view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Alphabet’s profit increased 36 percent, to $20.64 billion, in the fourth quarter.
description: The earnings by the parent company of Google were above analysts’ estimates.
content: These days, there is so much uncertainty surrounding Google’s parent company, Alphabet: a global pandemic, fears of inflation gripping the U.S. economy, restive employees challenging management, and regulators and politicians seemingly bent on taking their pound of flesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Pam & Tommy’ Review: The Internet Is for Porn
description: The raucous story of a stolen sex tape invites its audience to laugh, then asks what’s so funny.
content: Episode 4 of Hulu’s “Pam & Tommy” begins as the website pamsextape.com loads on a mid-90s IBM desktop computer — the gaudy typeface screaming “PAMELA’S HARDCORE SEX VIDEO,” the titillating photos of Pamela Anderson and her husband Tommy Lee loading one strip of pixels at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R.E. Hawley
title: Write It in Garamond
description: Creative output of any kind depends upon a steady stream of tiny self-delusions. A different font helps me believe in my own words.
content: I cannot start any document — a novel, a letter, an invoice — without first clicking on the drop-down menu labeled “Font” and considering my options. There are the obvious choices: Times New Roman, reliable if bland; Arial, crisp and austere; Proxima Nova, clean and versatile. But what about those occasions that require the fine china of typography?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Squared Up
description: Zhouqin Burnikel’s puzzle is a celebration of new beginnings.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Did you notice that, despite the headline on this column, today’s puzzle from Zhouquin Burnikel — known as C.C. to her fans — is in fact not square?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Former Pence Chief of Staff Has Testified to the Jan. 6 Committee
description: Marc Short, who has firsthand knowledge of former President Donald J. Trump’s pressure campaign on his vice president to throw out the election results, appeared under subpoena.
content: WASHINGTON — Marc Short, who served as chief of staff to former Vice President Mike Pence, testified privately last week before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the latest turn in weeks of negotiations between the panel’s investigators and Mr. Pence’s team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: International Orchestras Are Finally Back at Carnegie
description: The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra of London was the first foreign ensemble to play at the hall since February 2020.
content: What sets a cultural capital apart is not just the quality of its music-making, but also the quantity and variety. No American symphonic ensemble, for example, is better than the Cleveland Orchestra, but it stands largely alone at home. Few big groups travel to Cleveland the way they do to New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
title: A Year After Coup, Myanmar Is Mired in Conflict and Chaos
description: Daily protests, once loud and colorful, have been replaced by an eerie quiet. To mark the anniversary of the military takeover, protest leaders have called for a “silent strike.”
content: In the days after the military in Myanmar seized power on Feb. 1 last year, millions of people took to the streets to oppose the takeover, walking off their jobs in what has become an enduring nationwide civil disobedience movement and resisting the junta’s murderous violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Spotify Backs Joe Rogan’s Disinformation Machine
description: The streaming service picks Joe Rogan over Neil Young and Joni Mitchell.
content: The streaming service Spotify would like us to believe it is grappling with profound matters of free speech and censorship as it faces mounting pressure over repeated Covid disinformation from its star podcaster, Joe Rogan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch: The U.S. and Russia exchange bitter accusations at the U.N. Security Council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: How N.Y. Democrats Came Up With Gerrymandered Districts on Their New Map
description: The peculiar redrawing of Representative Jerrold Nadler’s district led to the joke that it was “jerrymandered.” The reasons for the new lines were politically complicated.
content: New York’s new congressional map, redrawn by ruling Democrats, gives the party’s candidates a clear leg up in nearly every corner of the state and could knock out as many as five Republican seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: States Are Complicating Corporate Pandemic Planning
description: Companies are wrestling with an array of state rules that makes designing pandemic policies tricky.
content: Now that the Biden administration’s nationwide coronavirus vaccine mandate for large companies has been overturned by the Supreme Court, employers are left to navigate a thicket of state and local rules. In New York, that means private employers have to require vaccines. In Florida and Texas, laws limit the pandemic protocols they can put in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On ‘The 7th Hand,’ Immanuel Wilkins Sees Jazz as an Escape Pod
description: The alto saxophonist’s second album is blues-based, gospel-infused, intellectually considered music that secures his quartet’s commanding status on the scene.
content: The alto saxophonist Immanuel Wilkins and his quartet make bristling, physical music, both leaning into and pulling against the swing rhythm that has historically been the backbone of jazz. There’s a certain sensuality to classic swing, an element of taking your time that doesn’t seem at home amid the hamster-wheel feeling of life today. Wilkins has wisely left that part behind in favor of a layered, exploding-grid approach to rhythm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Share Your Experience With Worker Tracking Systems
description: We’re interested in learning about how employers are monitoring and evaluating worker productivity.
content: We’d like to learn more about how employers are monitoring and evaluating worker productivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer is expected to ask the F.D.A. to authorize its Covid vaccine for children under 5.
description: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech are expected as soon as Tuesday to ask the Food and Drug Administration to authorize a coronavirus vaccine for children under 5 years old as a two-dose regimen while they continue to research how well three doses work.
content: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech are expected as soon as Tuesday to ask the Food and Drug Administration to authorize a coronavirus vaccine for children under 5 years old as a two-dose regimen while they continue to research how well three doses work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. expects production to return to normal this year as a chip shortage eases.
description: The company made $10 billion in profit for 2021, a 55 percent increase from 2020.
content: After a year of production disruptions due to a global computer chip shortage, General Motors said on Tuesday that its factories will be running at a normal clip again by the second half of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: City Harvest Moves Into an Expansive Space in Sunset Park, Brooklyn
description: Sushi, sashimi and steaks from a Las Vegas presence, a financial district outpost for Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar & Grill, and more restaurant news.
content: For nearly 40 years, City Harvest has collected food that would otherwise go to waste from restaurants, supermarkets, caterers, farms and others to supply soup kitchens, food pantries and the like. Now, it has moved into a 150,000-square-foot headquarters in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The organization had offices and food distribution centers in Manhattan and Queens, but the move has enabled it to consolidate all its operations in one location, which City Harvest says is the largest food rescue and distribution hub in the nation. “We have rescued and delivered over one billion pounds of food in our nearly 40-year history,” said Jilly Stephens, the organization’s chief executive. “More than 250 million of those pounds have been just since the start of the pandemic.” The chef Eric Ripert, who is vice chairman of the City Harvest board, added, “With this gigantic building, we could increase what we handle.” (Full disclosure: I wrote “City Harvest: 100 Recipes from Great New York Restaurants,” published in 2015 as a fund-raiser for the group.) The new building, designed by Ennead Architects, the Rockwell Group and Ware Malcomb, has refrigerated and ambient areas for food collection, loading docks, and by summer will also have an event space with a roof terrace that can be rented. Classes in nutrition will be open to the public, and there will be a street-level storefront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Pelly
title: How Poly Styrene Broke the Mold
description: A biracial woman in a predominantly white, male scene, the X-Ray Spex frontwoman brought fresh perspectives and sounds to punk. A new documentary explores her impact.
content: Poly Styrene beams out from the screen, smile wide, braces cemented across her teeth. In most images of first-wave punk musicians, their eyes are filled with negativity and contempt. In footage from a new film, Styrene’s are bright with possibility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: End Affirmative Action for Rich White Students, Too
description: Obviously.
content: My newsletter last week about illiberalism on the political right led to claims, in the Twittersphere and elsewhere, that I was engaging in “whataboutism” or “both-sides-ism,” perhaps even seeking absolution from the woke left by pointing to examples of censorship on the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Egan
title: I’m Lactose Intolerant. What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
content: Q. I’m lactose intolerant, but still enjoy milk in cereal and coffee. What is the best alternative, nondairy milk to drink?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tom Brady’s Impact Was Best Measured in Goose Bumps
description: Brady played perhaps the toughest position in sports with trademark ease. By doing so, he defined an era of explosive growth for the N.F.L.
content: Not surprisingly, Tom Brady’s time in the N.F.L. spotlight had an almost fairy-tale, prescient beginning. In a Super Bowl that is now 20 years past, Brady’s New England Patriots were two touchdown underdogs to the St. Louis Rams largely because Brady was a discarded apprentice thrust into a starting role when the marquee quarterback was injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda S. Spivack
title: Warehouse Space Is the Latest Thing Being Hoarded
description: Logistics firms are finding new options to deal with a scarcity of storage, including building multistory facilities and choosing locations farther from coastal ports.
content: As retailers and logistics companies try to stockpile goods to hedge against supply chain problems, they are facing a new challenge: In many parts of the United States, there is little to no space available to stash the merchandise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘My Best Friend Anne Frank’ Review: Separated by the Nazis
description: This film wants to spotlight a story of friendship and childhood innocence during the Holocaust, but feels quaint and misguided.
content: Anne Frank once lamented that she might survive the war and her friend, Hannah Goslar, probably would not. It’s a haunting perspective to remember when watching “My Best Friend Anne Frank,” a Dutch film told from the point of view of Hannah. Ben Sombogaart’s costume drama shuttles between Nazi-occupied Amsterdam, where Hannah and Anne are fast friends, and the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, where they were later imprisoned separately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah: Trump Is America’s Relentless Ex
description: “And like many exes, he really wants a second chance. But instead of promising to do better next time, he’s threatening to do even worse,” Noah said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Annotated by the Author: ‘Covid Test Misinformation Spikes Along With Spread of Omicron’
description: A reporter covering online disinformation takes you through how she debunks false information with the help of data, advice from experts and a little detective work.
content: As a resource for both our annual STEM-writing contest and our news literacy series, we asked Davey Alba, a technology reporter covering online disinformation and its global harms, to contribute to our Annotated by the Author series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levy
title: The Loneliest Mountaineer on Everest
description: The German climber Jost Kobusch is attempting to be the first to scale the world’s tallest mountain in winter alone without supplemental oxygen. There’s nobody else out there.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Amy Qin
title: As the U.S. Pulls Back From the Mideast, China Leans In
description: China is expanding its ties to Middle Eastern states with vast infrastructure investments and cooperation on technology and security.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In January alone, five senior officials from oil-rich Arab monarchies visited China to discuss cooperation on energy and infrastructure. Turkey’s top diplomat vowed to stamp out “media reports targeting China” in the Turkish news media, and Iran’s foreign minister pressed for progress on $400 billion of investment that China has promised his country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: New Friends and Secret Keepers: They Make N.B.A. Families Feel Welcome
description: A network of N.B.A. staffers helps players and their families find homes, hairstylists and everything else when they move to new cities.
content: Desireé LeSassier’s phone wouldn’t stop chiming. She had landed in Minneapolis about an hour before, on the Los Angeles Lakers’ plane, and people needed things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. National Debt Tops $30 Trillion as Borrowing Surged Amid Pandemic
description: The record red ink, fueled by spending to combat the coronavirus, comes as interest rates are expected to rise, which could add to America’s costs.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s gross national debt topped $30 trillion for the first time on Tuesday, an ominous fiscal milestone that underscores the fragile nature of the country’s long-term economic health as it grapples with soaring prices and the prospect of higher interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Report on London Police Highlights Culture of Misogyny and Racism
description: Britain’s police watchdog says the London force needs to address “disgraceful” behavior after an investigation found widespread bullying, discrimination and sexual harassment.
content: LONDON — London police officers routinely made jokes about rape and exchanged racist messages, according to a report from England’s official police watchdog that detailed a pattern of misogyny and bullying in the force, the latest blow to an embattled service that has faced intense scrutiny in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: A Race to Rethink Care After a Dire Diagnosis
description: With the backing of venture capital and well-known tech investors, Synapticure seeks to fill in the gaps in care and research for those with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
content: In August 2017, Brian Wallach’s notion of time changed forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: A Normal Supply Chain? It’s ‘Unlikely’ in 2022.
description: The chaos at ports, warehouses and retailers will probably persist through the year, and perhaps even longer.
content: With the havoc at ports showing no signs of abating and prices for a vast array of goods still rising, the world is absorbing a troubling realization: Time alone will not solve the Great Supply Chain Disruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Hungary’s leader, visiting Moscow, calls Russian demands reasonable and says sanctions are pointless.
description: On a friendly visit to Moscow, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary diverged sharply from his NATO and European Union allies.
content: MOSCOW — Splitting sharply from his NATO allies, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary said on Tuesday that proposed sanctions against Russia if it takes military action against Ukraine would be “doomed to failure” and that Russian security demands were reasonable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Your Mother Died. Now She Wants to Tell You Her Secrets.
description: Charmaine Wilkerson’s debut novel, “Black Cake,” shows how many times a woman can cook up a new life and what happens when she runs out of steam.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘The Violin Conspiracy’ Is a Musical Thriller With Some Unexpected Notes
description: Brendan Slocumb’s debut novel is a musical bildungsroman cleverly contained within a literary thriller.
content: THE VIOLIN CONSPIRACYBy Brendan Slocumb
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: 101 of the Best Songs About California
description: An unscientific guide to the tracks that evoke the Golden State.
content: With its dreamy landscapes and near year-round sunshine, California is the kind of place you could write songs about — and so many people have.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Covid Test Misinformation Spikes Along With Spread of Omicron’
description: In this lesson, students will consider viral Covid misinformation they may have seen, learn about how and why it spreads, and consider how to combat it.
content: Featured Article: “Covid Test Misinformation Spikes Along With Spread of Omicron”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple, Adam Westbrook and Jonah M. Kessel
title: Meet the People Getting Paid to Kill Our Planet
description: American agriculture is ravaging the air, soil and water. But a powerful lobby has cleverly concealed its damage.
content: “We’re Cooked” is an Opinion Video series about our broken food system and the three chances you get to help fix it — and save the planet — every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: In Clare Barron’s ‘Shhhh,’ Staging a Memoir of the Body
description: The playwright directs and stars in her new play for Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2. It’s less a traditional narrative and more of a series of flirtations with discomfort.
content: To get to your seat, you walk past someone’s toilet, stationed next to their sink, above which their pill bottles sit on a shelf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Smart Watch
description: Do you have one? Do you want one? Do think measuring your fitness is helpful?
content: In a recent Opinion essay, Lindsay Crouse, a marathon runner, writes about ditching her smart watch after she started to feel “addicted” to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Winter Storm Poised to Hit From Albuquerque to Detroit, Bringing Bitter Cold
description: Missouri and Illinois announced emergency plans. New Mexico, Texas and other areas unaccustomed to snow and freezing wind chills are bracing for days of frigid weather.
content: A blustery winter storm is expected to sweep through nearly 2,000 miles of the central United States starting on Tuesday evening, bringing a mix of freezing temperatures, heavy snow and potentially hazardous traveling conditions from parts of New Mexico and Texas up through Illinois and Michigan, weather officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Can the Fed Let Us Down Easy?
description: On inflation-fighting, 2022 isn’t 1980.
content: American workers are quitting at record rates, suggesting that they’re confident they can easily find new jobs. Wages are rising rapidly, suggesting that labor currently has a lot of bargaining power. These are the hallmarks of an economy at or near full employment. At the same time, inflation is running uncomfortably high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt and Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Had Role in Weighing Proposals to Seize Voting Machines
description: New accounts show that the former president was more directly involved than previously known in plans developed by outside advisers to use national security agencies to seek evidence of fraud.
content: Six weeks after Election Day, with his hold on power slipping, President Donald J. Trump directed his lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to make a remarkable call. Mr. Trump wanted him to ask the Department of Homeland Security if it could legally take control of voting machines in key swing states, three people familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: What the Joe Rogan Backlash Reveals About How We Handle Misinformation
description: Are we relying too heavily on  tech platforms to enforce the boundaries of socially acceptable speech?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Democrats Chase Shiny Objects. Here’s How They Can Build Real Power.
description: Amanda Litman makes the case for engaging with politics at the local level.
content: There’s good reason to worry about the future of democracy, and little reason to believe Democrats have a viable plan for protecting it. They built their strategy around passing a major suite of voting reforms and protections through Congress, and a few weeks back, their whole agenda collapsed in the face of the filibuster. So what now? Is there a Plan B for protecting democracy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK That I’m OK With Our Mom’s Adultery?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when disclosing a secret is a betrayal — and more.
content: Our dad died a year ago, and our mom recently told my sister and me that she cheated on him for the last 10 years of their marriage. I don’t think our dad ever knew; he wore his heart on his sleeve, so he couldn’t have hidden that sort of thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Brady set the GOAT bar.
description: With seven Super Bowl titles, his first two decades ago at age 24, Brady redefined success for N.F.L. quarterbacks.
content: So many details of Tom Brady’s career seem fanciful enough to sound apocryphal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: A Manager of a Certain Vintage
description: Baseball’s players may be locked out, but Dusty Baker, at 72, is hard at work in his vineyards, trusting advice from Willie Stargell and paying tribute to Henry Aaron.
content: SACRAMENTO — “Be right back,” Dusty Baker said on a chilly, recent Saturday morning at his home here. The veteran manager had made some final cuts earlier in the week and now it was time to pick up the pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz
title: Putin Signals Openness to Diplomacy While Blaming U.S. for Crisis
description: The Russian president seemed to be trying to ratchet down tensions in the standoff over Ukraine, while claiming the United States was seeking to goad Moscow into an invasion.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said on Tuesday that the United States was trying to pull Russia into an armed conflict over Ukraine that his government did not want and signaled he was prepared to engage in more diplomacy, even as he insisted that NATO’s presence in Eastern Europe threatened world peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer is expected to ask the F.D.A. to authorize its Covid vaccine for children under 5.
description: Pfizer and BioNTech in mid-December announced that two doses of the vaccine, given at a tenth of the amount of an adult dosing, did not produce a strong enough immune response in children ages 2 to 4.
content: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech are expected as soon as Tuesday to ask the Food and Drug Administration to authorize a coronavirus vaccine for children 6 months to 4 years old as a two-dose regimen while they continue to research how well three doses works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Shots for Young Kids
description: Pfizer asked the F.D.A. to authorize a vaccine for children under 5.
content: In a move eagerly anticipated by American parents, educators and pediatricians, Pfizer asked the F.D.A. today to authorize a two-dose regimen of its coronavirus vaccine for children under 5 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A diplomatic showdown at the U.N.
content: The U.S. and Russia engaged in a public diplomatic brawl Monday at the U.N. Security Council over the Ukraine crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Guns, Germs, Bitcoin and the Antisocial Right
description: The push to make Americans’ lives nasty, brutish and short.
content: In February 2021 a deep freeze caused widespread power outages in Texas, leaving about 10 million Texans without electricity, in many cases for days. Hundreds died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Bryan
title: To Reach Younger Viewers, the BBC Goes Back to the Airwaves
description: The British public broadcaster moved a youth-focused channel online, but now it’s changing course as viewing habits continue to mutate.
content: LONDON — When the BBC took its youth-focused TV channel off the air and moved it online in 2016, the broadcaster was going where its viewers seemed to be.
source.name: The New York Times

content: In her own words, top freeskier Eileen Gu describes finding the balance between confidence in her ability and the thrill of uncertainty.

title: How I Made It to the Beijing Olympics
description: China is hosting this year’s Winter Olympics in a bubble. For me, the bubble formed not in Beijing — but more than 5,000 miles away, at Charles de Gaulle Airport, outside of Paris.
content: China is hosting this year’s Winter Olympics in a bubble. For me, the bubble formed not in Beijing — but more than 5,000 miles away, at Charles de Gaulle Airport, outside of Paris.

description: For Olympians who spin in the air like kaleidoscopes, finding a landing spot is more dangerous when the sky is white like the ground.

title: U.S. Has Far Higher Covid Death Rate Than Other Wealthy Countries
description: Despite having one of the world’s most powerful arsenals of vaccines, the United States has failed to inoculate as much of its population as other wealthy nations.

description: The Ukrainian military is training civilians to help defend against a possible Russian invasion and occupation. Our cameras went inside a training center in the southeastern city of Mariupol.

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Behind Neil Young vs. Spotify, a Fraught Relationship With Musicians
description: The rocker touched off a debate about free speech and the responsibility of tech platforms. How many artists will follow him, now that streaming dominates the business?
content: Spotify arrived more than a decade ago with an appealing proposition: Listeners could leave their CDs and downloads behind and stream virtually every song ever released. It made the platform a top power in the music business and ushered in competitors like Apple Music, Amazon Music and Tidal, helping reverse the industry’s nosedive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 1, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 1, 2022.
content: An article on Saturday about efforts to aid Tonga following the recent volcanic eruption and tsunami misspelled the name of a Tongan community leader living in Melbourne, Australia. She is Mele Makelesi Facci, not Mele Malekesi Facci.
source.name: The New York Times
